     552             : 
     553             :     bool mDispatchingAsyncMessage;
     554             :     int mDispatchingAsyncMessageNestedLevel;
     555             : 
     556             :     // When we send an urgent request from the parent process, we could race
     557             :     // with an RPC message that was issued by the child beforehand. In this
     558             :     // case, if the parent were to wake up while waiting for the urgent reply,
     559             :     // and process the RPC, it could send an additional urgent message. The
     560             :     // child would wake up to process the urgent message (as it always will),
     561             :     // then send a reply, which could be received by the parent out-of-order
     562             :     // with respect to the first urgent reply.
     563             :     //
     564             :     // To address this problem, urgent or RPC requests are associated with a
     565             :     // "transaction". Whenever one side of the channel wishes to start a
     566             :     // chain of RPC/urgent messages, it allocates a new transaction ID. Any
     567             :     // messages the parent receives, not apart of this transaction, are
     568             :     // deferred. When issuing RPC/urgent requests on top of a started
     569             :     // transaction, the initiating transaction ID is used.
     570             :     //
     571             :     // To ensure IDs are unique, we use sequence numbers for transaction IDs,
     572             :     // which grow in opposite directions from child to parent.
     573             : 
     574             :     friend class AutoEnterTransaction;
     575             :     AutoEnterTransaction *mTransactionStack;
     576             : 
     577             :     int32_t CurrentNestedInsideSyncTransaction() const;
     578             : 
     579             :     bool AwaitingSyncReply() const;
     580             :     int AwaitingSyncReplyNestedLevel() const;
     581             : 
     582             :     bool DispatchingSyncMessage() const;
     583             :     int DispatchingSyncMessageNestedLevel() const;
     584             : 
     585             :     // If a sync message times out, we store its sequence number here. Any
     586             :     // future sync messages will fail immediately. Once the reply for original
     587             :     // sync message is received, we allow sync messages again.
     588             :     //
     589             :     // When a message times out, nothing is done to inform the other side. The
     590             :     // other side will eventually dispatch the message and send a reply. Our
     591             :     // side is responsible for replying to all sync messages sent by the other
     592             :     // side when it dispatches the timed out message. The response is always an
     593             :     // error.
     594             :     //
     595             :     // A message is only timed out if it initiated a transaction. This avoids
     596             :     // hitting a lot of corner cases with message nesting that we don't really
     597             :     // care about.
     598             :     int32_t mTimedOutMessageSeqno;
     599             :     int mTimedOutMessageNestedLevel;
     600             : 
     601             :     // Queue of all incoming messages.
     602             :     //
     603             :     // If both this side and the other side are functioning correctly, the queue
     604             :     // can only be in certain configurations.  Let
     605             :     //
     606             :     //   |A<| be an async in-message,
     607             :     //   |S<| be a sync in-message,
     608             :     //   |C<| be an Interrupt in-call,
     609             :     //   |R<| be an Interrupt reply.
     610             :     //
     611             :     // The queue can only match this configuration
     612             :     //
     613             :     //  A<* (S< | C< | R< (?{mInterruptStack.size() == 1} A<* (S< | C<)))
     614             :     //
     615             :     // The other side can send as many async messages |A<*| as it wants before
     616             :     // sending us a blocking message.
     617             :     //
     618             :     // The first case is |S<|, a sync in-msg.  The other side must be blocked,
     619             :     // and thus can't send us any more messages until we process the sync
     620             :     // in-msg.
     621             :     //
     622             :     // The second case is |C<|, an Interrupt in-call; the other side must be blocked.
     623             :     // (There's a subtlety here: this in-call might have raced with an
     624             :     // out-call, but we detect that with the mechanism below,
     625             :     // |mRemoteStackDepth|, and races don't matter to the queue.)
     626             :     //
     627             :     // Final case, the other side replied to our most recent out-call |R<|.
     628             :     // If that was the *only* out-call on our stack, |?{mInterruptStack.size() == 1}|,
     629             :     // then other side "finished with us," and went back to its own business.
     630             :     // That business might have included sending any number of async message
     631             :     // |A<*| until sending a blocking message |(S< | C<)|.  If we had more than
     632             :     // one Interrupt call on our stack, the other side *better* not have sent us
     633             :     // another blocking message, because it's blocked on a reply from us.
     634             :     //
     635             :     MessageQueue mPending;
     636             : 
     637             :     // Stack of all the out-calls on which this channel is awaiting responses.
     638             :     // Each stack refers to a different protocol and the stacks are mutually
     639             :     // exclusive: multiple outcalls of the same kind cannot be initiated while
     640             :     // another is active.
     641             :     std::stack<MessageInfo> mInterruptStack;
     642             : 
     643             :     // This is what we think the Interrupt stack depth is on the "other side" of this
     644             :     // Interrupt channel.  We maintain this variable so that we can detect racy Interrupt
     645             :     // calls.  With each Interrupt out-call sent, we send along what *we* think the
     646             :     // stack depth of the remote side is *before* it will receive the Interrupt call.
     647             :     //
     648             :     // After sending the out-call, our stack depth is "incremented" by pushing
     649             :     // that pending message onto mPending.
     650             :     //
     651             :     // Then when processing an in-call |c|, it must be true that
     652             :     //
     653             :     //   mInterruptStack.size() == c.remoteDepth
     654             :     //
     655             :     // I.e., my depth is actually the same as what the other side thought it
     656             :     // was when it sent in-call |c|.  If this fails to hold, we have detected
     657             :     // racy Interrupt calls.
     658             :     //
     659             :     // We then increment mRemoteStackDepth *just before* processing the
     660             :     // in-call, since we know the other side is waiting on it, and decrement
     661             :     // it *just after* finishing processing that in-call, since our response
     662             :     // will pop the top of the other side's |mPending|.
     663             :     //
     664             :     // One nice aspect of this race detection is that it is symmetric; if one
     665             :     // side detects a race, then the other side must also detect the same race.
     666             :     size_t mRemoteStackDepthGuess;
     667             : 
     668             :     // Approximation of code frames on the C++ stack. It can only be
     669             :     // interpreted as the implication:
     670             :     //
     671             :     //  !mCxxStackFrames.empty() => MessageChannel code on C++ stack
     672             :     //
     673             :     // This member is only accessed on the worker thread, and so is not
     674             :     // protected by mMonitor.  It is managed exclusively by the helper
     675             :     // |class CxxStackFrame|.
     676             :     mozilla::Vector<InterruptFrame> mCxxStackFrames;
     677             : 
     678             :     // Did we process an Interrupt out-call during this stack?  Only meaningful in
     679             :     // ExitedCxxStack(), from which this variable is reset.
     680             :     bool mSawInterruptOutMsg;
     681             : 
     682             :     // Are we waiting on this channel for an incoming message? This is used
     683             :     // to implement WaitForIncomingMessage(). Must only be accessed while owning
     684             :     // mMonitor.
     685             :     bool mIsWaitingForIncoming;
     686             : 
     687             :     // Map of replies received "out of turn", because of Interrupt
     688             :     // in-calls racing with replies to outstanding in-calls.  See
     689             :     // https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=521929.
     690             :     MessageMap mOutOfTurnReplies;
     691             : 
     692             :     // Stack of Interrupt in-calls that were deferred because of race
     693             :     // conditions.
     694             :     std::stack<Message> mDeferred;
     695             : 
     696             : #ifdef OS_WIN
     697             :     HANDLE mEvent;
     698             : #endif
     699             : 
     700             :     // Should the channel abort the process from the I/O thread when
     701             :     // a channel error occurs?
     702             :     bool mAbortOnError;
     703             : 
     704             :     // True if the listener has already been notified of a channel close or
     705             :     // error.
     706             :     bool mNotifiedChannelDone;
     707             : 
     708             :     // See SetChannelFlags
     709             :     ChannelFlags mFlags;
     710             : 
     711             :     // Task and state used to asynchronously notify channel has been connected
     712             :     // safely.  This is necessary to be able to cancel notification if we are
     713             :     // closed at the same time.
     714             :     RefPtr<CancelableRunnable> mOnChannelConnectedTask;
     715             :     bool mPeerPidSet;
     716             :     int32_t mPeerPid;
     717             : };
     718             : 
     719             : void
     720             : CancelCPOWs();
     721             : 
     722             : } // namespace ipc
     723             : } // namespace mozilla
